title: Implement TicketStore: Dolt embedded + MySQL server backends
description:
Implement the TicketStore interface with two backends: Dolt embedded mode (for local beads DBs) and MySQL/Dolt server mode (for remote beads instances).

## Context
- Beads stores issues in a Dolt database. Connection mode is determined by .beads/metadata.json in the target project.
- Embedded mode uses github.com/dolthub/driver â€” see tmp/store_embedded.go for reference patterns (DSN format, connector usage, pool config, backoff).
- Server mode uses standard MySQL driver (github.com/go-sql-driver/mysql) â€” see tmp/server-metadata.json for connection config shape.
- The issues table schema is in tmp/schema.go. There's also a ready_issues view that filters for unblocked work.
- This is READ-ONLY access. Blunderbuss never writes to the beads DB.

## Deliverables

### internal/data/dolt/embedded.go
- newEmbeddedStore(ctx, beadsDir) â€” opens embedded Dolt connection
- Read .beads/metadata.json to get database name
- DSN: file://<abs_path_to_.beads/dolt>?database=<db_name> (read-only, no committer needed)
- Connection pool: MaxOpenConns=1, MaxIdleConns=1 (embedded is single-connection)
- Implements TicketStore.ListTickets using ready_issues view

### internal/data/dolt/server.go
- newServerStore(ctx, beadsDir) â€” opens MySQL connection to Dolt server
- Read .beads/metadata.json for host, port, user, database
- Standard MySQL DSN
- Implements TicketStore.ListTickets using ready_issues view

### internal/data/dolt/store.go
- NewStore(ctx, beadsDir) â€” factory that reads metadata.json, picks embedded vs server mode
- Shared query logic (both modes use same SQL, different *sql.DB)
- ListTickets query: SELECT from ready_issues view, map to domain.Ticket
- Filter support: status, issue_type, search (LIKE on title), limit

### Metadata parsing
- Parse .beads/metadata.json to determine mode (check dolt_mode or presence of server fields)
- Current project's metadata.json: {database: dolt, backend: dolt, dolt_database: beads_bb} â†’ embedded
- Server example: adds dolt_mode: server, dolt_server_host, dolt_server_port, dolt_server_user

### Unit tests
- Metadata parsing (embedded detection, server detection)
- Query building with filters
- Use sqlmock for query tests (don't require running Dolt)

### CLI integration
- --beads-dir flag (default: .beads in current directory) to locate the beads database
- DSN override via --dsn flag for manual connection strings

## Key decisions
- Read-only: no writes, no transactions, no locking concerns
- Use ready_issues view for the default list (shows only unblocked, non-deferred, non-ephemeral)
- Embedded mode requires CGO (dolthub/driver uses CGO) â€” document this in README
- Fail loudly with actionable errors: DB not found, connection refused, schema mismatch

title: [FEATURE] One-shot tracer implementation
description:
### System Overview & Design Spec
To get from a Dolt database to a running tmux window, we need a clean pipeline. Here is the high-level architecture:
#### 1. The Data Layer (Beads/Dolt)
We need to interface with the Dolt database used by Beads. Since Dolt is MySQL-compatible, we will use a standard Go SQL driver to query for:
* **Tickets/Issues:** The active tasks you want to work on.
* **Metadata:** Contextual info that might need to be passed to the harness (branch names, repo paths).
#### 2. The Model Layer (Configuration)
Since harnesses (OpenCode, Claude, etc.) change frequently, we should define them in a `config.yaml` or `config.json`. This maps a "Harness" to a specific shell command template.
The TicketID will be used in a work prompt,
* **Attributes:** Name, Command Template (e.g., `opencode --model {{.Model}} --agent {{.Agent}}`), and supported Models/Agents.
#### 3. The UI Layer (Bubble Tea)
A multi-step TUI flow:
* **List View:** Select a Ticket (filtered from Beads).
* **Selection View:** Select Harness -> Select Model -> Select Agent (if applicable).
* **Execution:** Confirm and Launch.
#### 4. The Execution Layer (tmux/OS)
The Go binary will not just "run" a command; it will spawn a `tmux` window or pane.
* **Command:** `tmux new-window -n "Ticket-123" "harness_cmd_here"`
* **Tracking:** We can capture the window ID or PID if we want to monitor the process status later.
---
### Implementation Plan: Phase 1
We should start with a "Minimum Viable Launcher" that reads from the Dolt DB and triggers a tmux window.
## Feature Description
Keep this code nicely maintainable and extensible. Else it will be trashed even if it runs.
close_reason: MVP design complete (so far). Let the games begin

title: Bubble Tea TUI skeleton with multi-step navigation (fake data)
description:
Create the Bubble Tea program with all screens and state transitions using fake/in-memory data. This proves the UI flow works before wiring real backends.

## Deliverables

### internal/ui/app.go
- App struct holding Bubble Tea Model
- Constructor: NewApp(store TicketStore, loader Loader, launcher Launcher, opts AppOptions)
- AppOptions: DryRun bool, ConfigPath string, Debug bool

### internal/ui/model.go
- Main Model with step/screen state machine
- Steps: TicketList â†’ HarnessSelect â†’ ModelSelect â†’ AgentSelect â†’ Confirm â†’ Launching â†’ Result
- Back navigation (Esc) returns to previous step
- Quit (q/ctrl+c) from any screen

### Screen views (each in own file):
- internal/ui/ticket_list.go â€” List of tickets (table or list component), enter selects
- internal/ui/harness_select.go â€” List of harnesses from config, enter selects
- internal/ui/model_select.go â€” List of models for selected harness, enter selects (skip if only 1)
- internal/ui/agent_select.go â€” List of agents for selected harness, enter selects (skip if empty or only 1)
- internal/ui/confirm.go â€” Shows full selection summary + rendered command + rendered prompt, enter launches
- internal/ui/result.go â€” Shows launch result (success/failure), q quits

### Smart skipping
- If harness has only 1 model â†’ auto-select, skip to next
- If harness has 0 or 1 agents â†’ auto-select/skip
- If config has only 1 harness â†’ auto-select, skip

### Styling
- Use lipgloss for styling (it comes with Bubble Tea ecosystem)
- Keep it clean and minimal â€” this is a launcher, not a dashboard
- Use bubbletea list component (bubbles) for selection screens

### Wiring for this ticket
- Use FakeTicketStore with 5-10 hardcoded tickets
- Use hardcoded config with 2-3 harnesses
- Use FakeLauncher that prints command and returns success
- This MUST work standalone: go run cmd/blunderbuss/main.go should show the TUI with fake data

## Key decisions
- UI imports ONLY interfaces from internal/data, internal/config, internal/exec â€” never concrete implementations
- State machine is explicit (enum/const for steps, not implicit)
- Each screen is a sub-model with its own Update/View (Elm architecture)
- The confirm screen is important: user sees exactly what will happen before launch

title: Implement tmux launcher with dry-run and outside-tmux guard
description:
Implement the Launcher interface that spawns tmux windows with rendered harness commands. Include dry-run mode and a guard against running outside tmux (easily removable later).

## Deliverables

### internal/exec/tmux/launcher.go (implements Launcher interface)
- Launch(ctx, LaunchSpec) â†’ LaunchResult
- Constructs: tmux new-window -n "<WindowName>" "<RenderedCommand>"
- WindowName convention: ticket ID (e.g. bb-3zg)
- Captures tmux window ID from output if available
- Returns LaunchResult with window name, ID

### Dry-run mode
- When dry-run=true, print the command that would be executed, return fake LaunchResult
- Dry-run is passed through LaunchSpec or as a Launcher constructor option

### tmux guard
- Check TMUX env var on launcher construction
- If not inside tmux: return clear error ("blunderbuss must be run inside a tmux session")
- Design the guard as a simple check that can be removed/made optional later (e.g. a constructor option SkipTmuxCheck)

### internal/exec/tmux/runner.go
- CommandRunner interface: Run(ctx, name string, args ...string) ([]byte, error)
- RealRunner: wraps exec.CommandContext
- This abstraction exists purely for testability â€” keeps tmux out of unit tests

### internal/exec/tmux/status.go (monitoring foundation)
- TmuxWindowStatus type: Running, Dead, Unknown
- CheckStatus(windowName string) TmuxWindowStatus â€” uses tmux list-windows to check if window exists
- This is the MVP monitoring: is the window alive or not

### Unit tests
- Command construction (proper escaping, window naming)
- Dry-run returns expected output without executing
- Guard behavior (with/without TMUX env var)
- Status check logic (mock tmux list-windows output)

## Key decisions
- No shell interpretation: use exec.Command("tmux", "new-window", ...) not sh -c
- Window names are ticket IDs (short, unique, greppable)
- Guard is a soft architectural boundary â€” one bool to disable, not deep coupling
- Status check is basic (window exists = running, doesn't = dead) â€” extensible later per-harness

title: Wire real TicketStore into TUI with loading and error states
description:
Replace FakeTicketStore with the real Dolt-backed TicketStore. Add loading spinner and error handling for DB operations.

## Deliverables

### UI integration
- On app start: load tickets from real TicketStore asynchronously (Bubble Tea Cmd)
- Show loading spinner/message while querying
- Show error screen if DB connection fails, with actionable message (check beads dir, check DSN)
- Refresh capability (r key to reload ticket list)

### Error UX
- DB not found: "No beads database found at <path>. Is this a beads project?"
- Connection refused (server mode): "Cannot connect to Dolt server at <host>:<port>"
- Empty results: "No ready tickets found" (not an error, just info)

### cmd/blunderbuss/main.go updates
- Wire real NewStore(ctx, beadsDir) into app construction
- beadsDir from --beads-dir flag or auto-detect (.beads in cwd)
- Fallback to fake data if --demo flag is passed (preserves standalone testing)

## Key decisions
- Async loading via Bubble Tea commands (tea.Cmd), not blocking Init
- Error states are screens, not panics â€” user can quit gracefully
- Keep the --demo flag for development/testing convenience

title: Implement config.yaml loader with validation and template rendering
description:
Implement parsing/validation of harness definitions from YAML config and template rendering for both command and prompt strings.

## Deliverables

### internal/config/yaml.go (implements Loader interface)
- Parse YAML config file defining harnesses
- Validate: harness must have name, command_template; models/agents lists optional
- Return actionable error messages (missing field X in harness Y, file not found, parse error)

### internal/config/render.go
- RenderCommand(harness, templateContext) (string, error) â€” renders command template
- RenderPrompt(harness, templateContext) (string, error) â€” renders prompt template
- Uses text/template with the TemplateContext struct from domain
- Template errors are clear (which harness, which template, what went wrong)

### config.example.yaml
- Working example config showing 2-3 harnesses (e.g. opencode, claude-code, amp)
- Each harness shows command_template, prompt_template, models, agents
- Comments explaining each field

### Example config shape:
```yaml
harnesses:
  - name: opencode
    command_template: "opencode --model {{.Model}} --agent {{.Agent}}"
    prompt_template: "Work on ticket {{.Ticket.ID}}: {{.Ticket.Title}}"
    models: [claude-sonnet-4-20250514, o3]
    agents: [coder, task]
  - name: amp
    command_template: "amp"
    prompt_template: "Pick up {{.Ticket.ID}}"
    models: [claude-sonnet-4-20250514]
    agents: []
```

### Unit tests
- Parse valid config, parse invalid config (missing fields, bad YAML)
- Template rendering with full context, with missing optional fields
- Edge: empty models list, empty agents list, no prompt_template

## Notes
- YAML only for MVP. JSON support not needed.
- Templates use Go text/template â€” no custom functions needed yet
- Config path comes from CLI --config flag (default: ./blunderbuss.yaml)

title: [PRO] Define core domain types and service interfaces
description:
Create stable contracts between layers so later tickets can be implemented independently and tested with fakes. No real DB/tmux/UI logic â€” only types, interfaces, and minimal stub/fake implementations.

## Deliverables

### internal/domain/types.go
- Ticket struct: ID, Title, Description, Status, Priority, IssueType, Assignee, CreatedAt, UpdatedAt (match beads issues table schema â€” see tmp/schema.go for full column list, cherry-pick what's useful for display and context)
- Harness struct: Name, CommandTemplate (Go text/template string), PromptTemplate (Go text/template string), SupportedModels []string, SupportedAgents []string, Env map[string]string
- Selection struct: Ticket + Harness + Model + Agent (the user's complete choice)
- LaunchSpec struct: Selection + RenderedCommand string + RenderedPrompt string + WindowName string
- LaunchResult struct: WindowName, WindowID (optional), PaneID (optional), Error
- Config struct: Harnesses []Harness, Defaults (optional, for future quickdraw/blitzdraw)

### internal/domain/template_context.go
- TemplateContext struct â€” the fat context passed to both command and prompt templates. Include everything: Ticket fields, Harness name, Model, Agent, Repo path, Branch, etc. Generous â€” templates pick what they need.

### internal/data/store.go
- type TicketStore interface { ListTickets(ctx context.Context, filter TicketFilter) ([]domain.Ticket, error) }
- TicketFilter struct: Status, IssueType, Limit, Search

### internal/config/loader.go
- type Loader interface { Load(path string) (*domain.Config, error) }

### internal/exec/launcher.go
- type Launcher interface { Launch(ctx context.Context, spec domain.LaunchSpec) (*domain.LaunchResult, error) }

### internal/data/fake/, internal/exec/fake/
- FakeTicketStore and FakeLauncher for testing and UI development without real deps

## Key design decisions
- UI depends ONLY on interfaces + domain types, never on concrete implementations
- Template context is intentionally generous â€” security is not a concern (launching tools with broad access anyway)
- TicketFilter is kept simple for MVP â€” no pagination yet
- Interfaces are minimal (one method each where possible) â€” easy to implement, easy to fake

title: Bootstrap Go module, repo layout, and build scaffolding
description:

- CLI framework: keep it simple (stdlib flag or cobra â€” agent's call, but be consistent)
- Project layout follows standard Go project layout (cmd/, internal/)
